Posts.Content: Aug 2, 2010 12:57PM chainsawz wrote: This disease really does suck, but just know there is always hope.  Medicine is always moving forward and new treatments are always on the horizon.  I get herceptin for my her2+ cancer - that was not available 15 years ago and women did not have the chance I do now.  I also take tykerb for my her2+ and brain mets......that wasn't around too many years ago.  It gives me an even better chance and may give me some time with that cool guy NED!    The frameless cyberknife used to treat my brain mets and give me a year of clear MRI's wasn't available many moons ago.  It's here now...I was treated and went to work at my full time job the next day.  You never know what might be right around the corner! I was dx'd at 44, and I thought I was too young.  It happens to us at all ages :<  I just try to focus on the right here and right now.  Not the past or future.  That helps me get out of bed and get thru the day.  You will find your footing on this rocking stage IV ship....it just takes a little time.  Just know we are here for you on this journey!!  lisa
Posts.Title: Serious denial... texasrose361 texasrose361

Posts.Content: Mar 30, 2010 01:30PM chainsawz wrote: There is a great thread on the surgery forum called shopping\packing\to do:  http://community.breastcancer.org/forum/91/topic/699896?page=2#idx_31 You might get some good tips from there.  It was nice to have someone around to help with my drains - I had mine in for a month but most people get them out after 3 to 7 days.  I felt okay unless I moved (bmx w/o reconstruction).  I got a piece of string and attached my drains to that.....really helped in the shower.  The best piece of advice I got was to get a big button up shirt, and to move things I used a lot down to a counter.  It will be difficult for you to reach glasses, shampoo and things that are up high...at least for a few days.  \ You'll do great!!

Posts.Content: Mar 26, 2010 11:35AM chainsawz wrote: I had to stop xeloda, so I am only on tykerb & herceptin for now.  Poop soup is the main SE for me.  I get rashes and crazy pimples that I treat with clinamyacin gel.  I take immodium for the diarrhea.  My joints hurt a bit, but it is much kinder than TCH for sure!!   I have read many have hand foot syndrome with xeloda.  Bag balm is used lots and Heather P started a good thread here - I think it was called Hand Food Syndrome - thinking outside of the box.  Everyone put in their way of dealing with this SE.  One interesting one was the use of lidocaine patches on the feet when they got really bad.  I think this combo definitely has some SE, but report them to your onc and they may reduce your dose.  The tykerb gave me a HUGE rash/hives/pimples all over and my dose had to be reduced and it is much better!  Good luck on the trial and keep us updated!!

Posts.Content: Jul 26, 2010 05:33PM - edited Jul 26, 2010 05:34PM by chainsawz This is the link for Christine's story - I didn't realize she had gamma before WBR!  She was dx stage 4 in 1999: http://her2support.org/community/member-stories/217-brain-talk-volume-6-number-2 And here's what she posted in response to a thread called "has anyone ever been cured?" (this was posted on another ABC site)  I hope she does not mind me reposting on this site, but it I think it is so important for us to know there are some good stories out there!  Posted May 3, 2010 at 5:12 am There are rare cases of cures. One of the best documented is Barbara Bradfield who achieved a complete clinical cure after participating in the Phase I Trial of Herceptin in 1993, She has not had to take any chemo since the trial ended 17 years ago. Another is Ginger Empey who was the first patient enrolled in the Phase III trial in 1995. Ginger discontinued chemo in Sept. 2008. I was first diagnosed at stage IV in 1999 with brain mets and tumors in my chest. I was treated with Herceptin for nine years and stopped all chemo in November 2008 after consulting with Dr. Dennis Slamon. The three of us remain cancer free, there are others whose stories on on the HER2 Support Group's website: http://her2support.org/community/member-stories Please don't misinterpret this as I am not advocating that all Stage IV bc survivors on Herceptin should discontinue treatment as this is a very serious decision that should not be fully discussed with your oncologist. But it does happen !! Hugs Christine I just read a post from yet another woman on another site who was on herceptin for 8.5 years and has been off everything for the last year.  Her onc wants her to go back on herceptin, and she is posting because she is hesitant....the year break was nice for her :>  There is always hope!!!

Posts.Content: Dec 28, 2010 01:47PM chainsawz wrote: English major posted on this subject a while back....there are two types of bone mets, one can only be seen by the pet and the other only by CT. http://community.breastcancer.org/forum/8/topic/760022?page=1#post_2055542 Oct 29, 2010 07:07 pm EnglishMajor wrote: http://www.cancer.org/Cancer/BoneMetastasis/DetailedGuide/bone-metastasis-diagnosis Regular x-rays of the bones may show signs of the cancer's spread. There are 2 types of bone metastases. In osteolytic or lytic metastases, the cancer cells dissolve some of the minerals in the bone, making an area of the bone less dense. If the cancer has destroyed enough of the bone's substance, these appear on x-rays as a darker hole in the gray-white bone image ["Swiss Cheese like"]. Bones with osteolytic metastases tend to break very easily. Osteoblastic or blastic metastases cause an area of the bone to appear denser or sclerotic ["scar like"]. On x-rays, these metastases show up as spots that are whiter than the bone around them. . Often, bone metastases have both lytic and blastic features. Sometimes bone scans fail to find cancer that has spread to the bones. This happens most often if the metastases are purely osteolytic (where bone is less dense). In some patients, the scan may show no radioactivity in areas of bone that the cancer has already destroyed. In some cases, a CT scan can help tell if the cancer has spread into your bones. It may be used when bone metastases are only osteolytic, since these metastases sometimes don't show up in bone scans.   Because an MRI scan is very useful for looking at the spine and spinal cord, it is the standard test used if spinal cord compression is suspected. MRIs are also good at finding problems in bones and joints. Often an MRI scan is done to better define a bone mass seen on an x-ray. MRI scans can usually tell if the mass is likely to be a tumor, an infection, or some type of bone damage from other causes.

Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2010 02:33PM chainsawz wrote: I don't know if they can biopsy brain mets.  Mine were inoperable so there was no way to get to them.  They said they could tell they weren't benign by the structures and that they were in two different locations.  I guess brain mets follows a particular pattern so they don't know for sure, but can have a good idea.  I wish the science was better, but it has been moving in leaps and bounds in the last 10 years.  I don't know anything about liver because my other mets are lung, but I would hope they could get a decent biopsy using a CT scanner!  My largest met was 9mm and they managed to hit it.  I did tell them to knock met out with happy juice for the procedure and they did.  I also told them when I felt pain, I began kicking violently....maybe that helped!  I was out for the whole thing.  I would ask if they can do a biopsy with a ct scanner instead of ultrasound and request - no.....demand sedation for your mom!

Posts.Content: Feb 9, 2010 02:21PM chainsawz wrote: Michelle - I am sorry to hear about your mom's troubles :<  Brain mets can be treated and many people who respond to treatment are around and kicking - me being one of them!   I am on herceptin and tykerb....tykerb is believed to pass the BBB (blood brain barrier) and help treat brain mets.  I only had 2 lesions, so I was a candidate for cyberknife, but I believe with 7 they will steer her towards WBR.  I have read posts from other women who had successful WBR and then were able to treat any left over spots with cyberknife.  I would definitely talk with her onc about tykerb, tho.  As for your asymmetry - from what I have read that means one side looks different than the same location on the other side and they want to watch this closely. Doesn't mean cancer, but it worries the docs.  I'm not an expert, but you can google breast asymmetry and find better info that what I am probably writing here :> Just know there is hope for your mom!  There is also a great site to look at regarding brain mets and her2+ because information will be important for you.  It is more common for her2+ than many realize and can respond to treatment, but we tend to get clumped in with all cancer patients by the radiology oncologists.  Here's the link:   http://home.earthlink.net/~ckane/bcwatchdigest-brain.htm

Posts.Content: Jul 2, 2010 11:59AM chainsawz wrote: I worked for an major insurance carrier, and usually if you call and complain they will adjust the claim and pay the bill.  I had a similar thing happen.  I went to the hospital for my heart echo, and the dr who read the report was out of network so I got charged.  I could never pick the doc so it is very unfair.  I called my insurance company and they immediately adjusted and paid the claim.  If they don't adjust, then keep going up the ladder...ask for a supervisor and be very vocal.  You can also appeal.  Let them know you are going to be a big pain in the rear :> I also called the hospital to complain and let them know they need to change their policies or I would not schedule services there and pass the word on.  Good luck!!

Posts.Content: Jun 7, 2010 12:59PM chainsawz wrote: Hi there....sorry you have to join us, but you will find amazing people here to help you on this journey.  I don't see any stats for you.  Are you er\pr positive or her2+??  There are different protocols for triple negatives, versus her2+ gals, etc.  I research and learn everything....I use my information to challenge my onc.  If he didn't like it, I would fire him!  He treats all cancers.  I have her2+ breast cancer, and he does not soley specialize in that so he can't possibly know everything... he is not afraid to tell me that either :>  If I have research or questions, he is happy to delve into the research more and help guide me thru the maze.  That's what you pay them for.  He\she should always want your input and decisions.  Good for you!!  So many people just go along with whatever and don't want to know the details.  I am not like that at all.  This is my life and I am fighting for it! As for statistics....there just aren't any good ones out there.  They are so many new things out, we are the ones making the statistics.  I do know with treatment I can have many, many years.  Without, I am looking at not much time.  Hugs to you!  lisa

Posts.Content: Feb 12, 2010 02:50PM chainsawz wrote: When you catch your breath - read this: http://home.earthlink.net/~ckane/bcwatchdigest-brain.htm It has information so you know about your options.  When my brain mets were first discovered, I was told WBR was the standard treatment after cyberknife.  I did research and discovered a different protocol for her2+ bc patients.  We are found to have them more commonly and survive for years and years after their discovery....and that WBR did not extend our lives more than just cyberknife alone.  You can only do WBR once, and I wanted to save that big gun for later and I still work full time so I didn't want to risk any cognitive deficits.  I took this research to my onc, neurosurgeon and rad onc and dug in my heels until they agreed.  This is all very new territory, so you have to be your own advocate.  Lots of information to absorb, so I will leave it at that because I know your head is swirling.  Have some wine and chocolate and just know you will get your footing again :>

Posts.Content: Mar 24, 2011 03:00PM chainsawz wrote: I googled your question and got this from ehow..... Are Debts Forgiven When Someone Dies? When someone dies, he often leaves debts. Perhaps a mortgage, car payment, or unpaid student loans. These debts might not be forgiven, but they might not be recoverable either. And his family isn't always stuck with the debt. Debts Debts do not die with the deceased. Although death creates an emotional burden on survivors, debts--and any money owed to the deceased--must be addressed. Even Uncle Sam will want his money, so tax returns must be filed, creditors contacted, plans made. However, some debts are forgiven after the debtor dies; these can include credit card accounts and other credit accounts such as federal student loans. It is important to take a close look at the deceased's circumstances. The Heirs Relatives and heirs to the estate are not required to repay the deceased's debts. However, because the estate must pay back all debts required (not forgiven) and possible (assuming the money does not run out), the inheritance might shrink or disappear. Also, if you are a co-signer or co-owner on a debt with the deceased, you are generally responsible for at least a portion of the debt. Otherwise, heirs and relatives cannot be forced to pay.

Posts.Content: Feb 16, 2010 11:39AM chainsawz wrote: Elizabeth - I thought I'd post more details for you and anyone else facing brain mets who qualify for SRS (stereotactic radiosurgery) I had "Frame-less Stereotactic Radiosurgery".  This involved a plastic mask being molded to my face and that was bolted to the table....not my head. I had a planning CT and then an MRI a week before so they could map my spots.  Then, I went for the actual procedure which was painless and took 40 minutes per mets.  It was like having an x-ray.  Very easy, and I went to work the next day.  I was told to expect fatigue, but I never did. I have read many posts from other BC patients who had the "old" framed method where patients were required to have a metal head ring attached to their skull with four pins. From what I read this was not always a pleasant process.  If possible, I would encourage everyone to locate a facility that uses the a system that allows "frame-less" stereotactic radiosurgery, which is just as accurate and much easier....this is just my opinion, but thought I would throw this out there.... You are such an inspiration to us all...you are facing this awful beast but I see you are out there giving support to others without missing a beat....no wonder you are so loved!!!

You are a strong person, so I know you will do great when you talk with your mom.  Once she sees you are still the same she will be more relaxed about the whole thing. However, when I am not getting my way I still grab my forehead and wince............. I am going to borrow your silly walking even tho mine were in a different spot - that should go over big at work....LOL!!!  Thanks for all the great ideas Elizabeth!!

Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2011 10:08PM chainsawz wrote: I also have lung mets.....size is important because it can't be biopsied if it is too small.  I had a lung biopsy and it definitely was not fun...bleck.  I had the procedure because this was my first discovered site of mets and we wanted to know for sure it was bc and the pathology was the same as my breast.  Once it was confirmed as mets and stable, we just watched...scanned every 3 months.  Now that I have progression in my lungs I am having stereotactic radiation to the two active spots and then some lovely chemo.  The idea of waiting can be good because if you are stable you want to save those guns for later.....it's about a marathon so you have to pace yourself :>

Posts.Content: chainsawz wrote: I just had my third infusion in a row today of Navelbine....that stuff kicked my butt even more than taxotere\carboplatin...and that's saying alot :<  Today, my onc reduced my dose by 20% so I am hoping that helps, but I have a weird SE even with the dose reduction.  During my infusion, I start to get this intense feeling that I have a lump in my throat and stomach....not nice.  They added zantac as a pre-med and that seems to help a bit, but I still have the discomfort for the whole day.  I've tried to eat something during the infusion, and today I am chewing on some tums to see if that will help. One of the nurses said it was some type of neuropathy?  Has anyone experienced this and found anything that helps??  Lisa -mets to lungs & brain - clear lymph nodes.....the weakest step toward the top of the hill, toward sunrise, toward hope, is stronger than the fiercest storm. Posts.Title: Navelbine...feels like a lump in my throat?? chainsawz chainsawz

Posts.Content: May 11, 2011 02:39PM chainsawz wrote: I just read up on cricopharyngeus spasm - it sounds just like fits my symptoms!!  I get temporary relief when I drink or eat something, but otherwise that feeling is there.  That muscle is in the esophagus and is always contracted, unless food or drink is passing by...then it relaxes.  The spasm is a hyper contraction of the muscle and can feel like there is a golf ball or phlegm caught in there.    How interesting they were just talking about it on the halaven thread - I'll have to check it out.  I'm still digging for ways to find relief besides constantly drinking and eating!!

Posts.Title: Preserve the peace Bernicky lwd

Posts.Content: chainsawz wrote: I consider myself a very strong and positive person who can stand up against most anything that is thrown at me, but I am having a hard time at the moment. I'm sad and just need to vent to help me get over something which shouldn't even bother me in light of everything I have dealt with in the last year....specifically brain mets.  Why on earth would any stupid little crap bother me?  But it does and I can't tell my partner or family - they would be very upset. My partner and I have been together for over 11 years.  My sister in law basically became scarce after my diagnosis in 2008.  I noticed, but didn't say anything.  This summer, on the day we found out about my brain mets (you can imagine it was a very upsetting day)   SIL called my partner and needed to chat about something in her life - my partner explained what was going on and they couldn't talk right now.  My SIL got upset and said she wished she could have two hours with her family without cancer.  Shocked, my partner said that the family has not been supportive - only my family.  There was a lot of emotion at that moment, but my SIL snarled "you'll live to regret that" and slammed down the phone.  We haven't heard from her since.....over 6 months.  I, being the eternal optimist, sent my SIL a really nice Christmas card (against my partner's wishes) addressed to her from both of us - I signed both our names.  I was trying to help mend the fences between them a little.  To my surprise, a beautiful card arrived in the mail yesterday......but addressed to only my partner.....very deliberately.  I shouldn't be surprised or upset because this is the type of person she is, but I can't help being hurt that someone in the world thinks so little of me to do this just because I have cancer.  What is wrong with people?   Am I the only one dealing with something like this? Lisa -mets to lungs & brain - clear lymph nodes.....the weakest step toward the top of the hill, toward sunrise, toward hope, is stronger than the fiercest storm. Posts.Content: Jan 10, 2010 02:21PM chainsawz wrote: I am taking tykerb and got a horrible rash on the back of my thighs not too long ago.  Whatever I put on it just made it worse.....clindamycin....hydrocortisone.  Nothing seemed to help.....only time helped.  It started to go away after a week or two.  It didn't itch, but was definitely ugly and really worried me.  It seems this is pretty common.  If you are experiencing tightness in your throat, shortness of breath or the rash seems to be spreading rapidly then you should go get seen immediately.  Nothing was ever done for my rash.  I was told if it kept happening, then we should talk about altering the dose.   I now just get bumps here and there (every place on my body) and they go away after a few days.  Best to you!!

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2010 09:26AM chainsawz wrote: I started on xeloda and tykerb but had a rare reaction called cardiac artery vasospasms which caused me to feel like I was having a heart attack.  The pain was in my back, chest and radiated into my jaw and left arm.  Awful!  I stopped the xeloda and then added my herceptin back with the tykerb and have been on that for 6 months now and having good success.   At first they did not believe I has having a reaction to xeloda.....seems some of us just don't tolerate it well at all.  The SE with tykerb are manageable, and I certainly don't have much nausea which is a great relief to me.  I hope you got some relief for this horrible SE you are experiencing!  Please let us know how you are doing :>

Posts.Content: Jan 6, 2010 05:33PM chainsawz wrote: I agree with Elizabeth - you are very considerate to come here and ask :>  When I was diagnosed with stage iv one of my good friends told me his neighbor was a bc survivor.  He acknowledged I was at a different stage, so it wasn't the same, but that his neighbor said if I had any questions at all she would be pleased to talk with me.  I never did call her since I seem to get all I need from the online communities (like this one!), but it really touched me that she was willing to support me if I needed her.   In reality, your sister will be the one who can offer her the best support....just being there for her friend.  Driving her to treatments, taking her to lunch.....just listening to her when she needs a shoulder and holding her when she needs to cry.
Posts.Title: How do I deal with this???? scrappy_survivor noblegases

Posts.Content: Jul 18, 2010 02:38PM chainsawz wrote: {{{{jennifer}}}}  I'm so sorry you had to go thru this at work :<  I work full time and while I haven't experienced your pain level, I know how hard it is to have to be there when everything is at its worst.  I had to go into a meeting after finding out about my brain mets......it took all my strength to sit in that meeting listening to such benign issues when I was just confronted with such a scary thing.....and no one in the room had a clue.  Even if I told them, they just wouldn't understand or get the depth of what was happening.  I just focused on my breathing....told myself to breathe in and to breathe out...and that I can do this and will do this.  If you didn't run out of that place screaming like a banshee, then I think you did an amazing job!  Now when I am in a large meeting, my mind always starts to wonder and worry about having a seizure right there and then.....then I get panicked.  I usually start to tap my leg so I can try to refocus myself before I have a full freak out.  I don't know how I would deal with the pain and I hope someone will come along with some better suggestions.  Just know you are one tough cookie for finishing the day!!!

Posts.Content: Oct 13, 2009 05:28PM chainsawz wrote: While my cancer was only in one breast, I opted for a bilateral mastectomy.  The post surgical pathology on my breast showed it was chock-full of more in-situ cancer.  I had a breast MRI, ultrasounds and multiple mammos on that breast and only my primary tumor showed up......not all the other dangerous stuff.  Luckily my insurance or doctors did not balk when I demanded the bilateral mastectomy because I really don't see how all that undetected cancer could not have caused me more trouble down the line.  Best to you!!  lisa

Posts.Content: Feb 17, 2011 04:00PM chainsawz wrote: Interesting!  It's been around for quite a while.  I read up on it, but found the best explanation on wikipedia. It sounds like they use it more for tumors closer to the skin, right?  I'm not really clear on if it is useful for bone or organ mets? http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electrochemotherapy When a biological cell is exposed to an electric field of sufficient strength, an increase in the trans-membrane voltage is generated, which leads to structural rearrangements of the cell membrane structure. These changes result in an increase of the cell membrane permeability, which allows nonpermeant molecules to enter the cell. This phenomenon is called cell electroporation (or electropermeabilisation) and is becoming widely used to improve anticancer drug delivery into cells, which is being referred to as electrochemotherapy.

Posts.Content: Jan 14, 2010 09:22AM chainsawz wrote: Carol - I was diagnosed with lung mets from the get go and had 6 rounds of TCH which finished a year ago.  I felt the same way - it knocked my socks off and I felt horrible.  You will get thru this....you will feel better.....right now the wind is just knocked out of your sails.  I would sit on my bed and cry because I was tired of being tired.  It is hard, but you will catch your breath and get up and fight.  Drink lots of water to help flush it out of your system and just know that this is not forever.  I have been working full time since I finished TCH and haven't missed a beat - even with my brain mets treatments....there is life after TCH!!   There is a good thread on the chemotherapy board called taxotere, carboplatin and herceptin...you might get some more tips there?  That's where I read a good tip to take claritin and aleve to combat the bone pain from the neulasta (newnasty) shot.  It really helped me.  Hang in there!

Posts.Content: Dec 27, 2009 10:57PM chainsawz wrote: Carol, I did 6 rounds of that combo last year.  The last two treatments were the hardest.  Like Fitz, my fatigue was big.....I was on 4 different nausea meds which might also have something to do with that.  I went on short term disability - I took the whole six months off.  Every person is different.  Some have lots of side effects, and others hardly have any. It's not fun, but it is doable.  I did lose every hair on my body...even my nose hairs :>  It was nice to have a break from shaving!  Do you have short term disability at your job?  If you feel okay then you can go back to work, but if not you have that and FMLA in place.     There is a thread about this going on in the forum - chemo before, during and after called: taxotere, carboplatin, herceptin.  Here's the link: http://community.breastcancer.org/forum/69/topic/578284?page=209#post_1641869 There are probably some other good threads in the Her2+ forum.  Best to you!

Posts.Content: Nov 16, 2009 01:01AM chainsawz wrote: I am so sorry you have these painful things.  I had a few and I bought biotin mouthwash from the drug store and used that 3 times a day and that helped my small sores and kept new ones at bay.  When I got some that weren't helped by biotin, I had my oncologist call in a script for a special numbing mouthwash.  You can get the recipe by googling magic mouth wash - that helped me with the pain.  Also, have you been to the dentist lately?  Chemo does a number on our teeth and mouth.  I had an abcess on one of my teeth and didn't even realize that was going on.  I hope you get some relief soon!  lisa

Posts.Content: Aug 28, 2010 03:01PM chainsawz wrote: I am not triple negative, but I have a chemo buddy who is, and she has been on maintenance chemo for 2 years now.  She was on taxol/avastin, which did thin her hair a little (I could never tell!) but she has a nice head of hair.  Taxotere is harsh, but can kick some stage IV cancer butt!!  We need the big guns to get a dance with NED.  My hair started growing back before I even finished my 6 rounds.  The meds I am on now have slowed the growth, but I have hair.  I love the phrase "it's air not hair", but it doesn't make being bald for a long period of time (or forever) any easier.  Hugs to you my sister...this journey is definitely not an easy one.  Betty Davis said "growing old is not for sissies"....well, stage IV cancer is not for sissies either!  xx00xx

Posts.Content: Jan 20, 2010 10:14PM chainsawz wrote: Hezzy - I have the same problem - I gag everytime I have to swallow my immodium pills because they are big and chalky (I now get the smaller pills).  So, I was completely freaked out about swallowing 5 tykerb pills a nite!!  I was kind of beside myself and was begging for IV chemo because I just didn't think I could do it at all!  I did talk with the pharmacy and they said I could cut them in half if I needed to.  I started taking them Aug 09 and have not had a problem one time taking them!  I was completely amazed!  They appear big, but they are shaped just right, smooth or something.....whatever it is they just slide down.  I've not had a problem with one.  They have zero taste so if they sit in my mouth a second, my taste buds don't freak out....there's not after taste either.  I do take them with a full glass of water and try to drink extra during the day.  But I have to tell you, it's been 6 months and never a problem......no tricks just swallowing.  I also have problems with a swollen throat and uvula and these pills have still not been a problem so I think you will be okay! I take mine right before bed - that seems to work best for me.  Tykerb is supposed to get up into the BBB, so I think this is an awesome choice for us!!  Feel free to pm me :>

Posts.Content: Feb 9, 2010 05:32PM chainsawz wrote: I had two spots in my brain - 5mm in thallmus, 5 1/2mm R front lobe which I think is the cerebellum.  I did research and found that brain mets is more common in her2+ and that smaller lesions that are under 4 in number can successfully be treated with SRS (cyberknife) and that WBR did not extend our lives.  I had mine treated 07/09 and now have had two clear MRI's.  If I get more, I plan to insist on more cyberknife and will hold out for WBR until later.  I had to present my research to the rad onc because this is all new territory for them.  Here a link to a great site:  http://home.earthlink.net/~ckane/bcwatchdigest-brain.htm I would agree with Elizabeth and say you are definitely NOT a baby and no this is not too small to  be treated!  I would insist it be treated ASAP with SRS (stereotactic radiosurgery) if available in your area.  I had a plastic mask fitted to my face, not the other procedure where they screw a halo into your skull.  I would find a place with new machines that can use the mask :>  Best to you!!

Posts.Content: Aug 14, 2011 02:51PM chainsawz wrote: I went to three different docs......a lung surgeon to talk about wedge resection, another about RFA and then my rad onc to talk about stereotactic body therapy (radiation).  I decided that the lung wedge resection was not for me.  Painful recovery, and they take a good chunk of lung.  Besides I have mets and it would be a waste if another mets showed up.  I finally decided on the SRBT because it was the least invasive, had the same % of success and could be repeated if needed.  I am NOT a fan of leaving mets to grow, so I knew I was going to zap my two stubborn spots somehow.  You should interview all three options and see which one appeals to you.
Posts.Title: Surgery to Remove Lung Mestastases Tina2 rkt

Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2010 02:40PM chainsawz wrote: Hey sincity - I have zero experience with abraxane, but I have seen threads about it so I thought I'd jump in here and post the links.  Maybe you can find some useful info or post to them and chat with those who are on it?  Best of luck to your mom~!! I also copied the blurb below from another thread in the stage I and II forum which the poster copied from the triple negative forum...LOL!!!  http://community.breastcancer.org/forum/108/topic/748340?page=1#post_1719778 Abraxane v Taxol (comment from TNBC forum) "Hey, I just heard a talk on Abraxane vs Taxol, and Abraxane appears to be both more efficacious and with fewer side effects.  Abraxane consists of nanoparticles of albumin arranged in a sphere with taxol inside.  Because of the improved efficacy (weekly is best, at 150mg), Abraxane will probably become standard of care.  With Avastin it works even better, as chemotherapy causes cancer cells that don't die to overexpress VegF (proangiogenesis and creating resistance to chemo), and Avastin shuts down the VEGF circuitry. "

Posts.Content: Sep 25, 2010 06:38PM chainsawz wrote: I started off stage IV and my lymph nodes were clear.  It can spread either via the lymph nodes or the blood stream.  From what I understand, the lymph nodes act as filters for the body.  They attempt to stop the cancer from spreading. BC mets IMHO is not clearly understood yet....still lots to learn.  Some women can have a very large tumor and mess nodes and never get mets.  Others can have a tiny tumor and clean nodes and gets mets.  It just happens sometimes and one day science will figure it all out.  I am not an expert, but I would think lymph nodes are a good thing to have if they are free of cancer.  The more filters the merrier!!!

Posts.Content: Oct 13, 2009 03:41PM chainsawz wrote: I think many of us with stage IV feel left behind by the whole pink campaign.  I really appreciate all the funding it has brought forth - and I have benefited directly from Susan G. - don't get me wrong.  However, I think it needs to be focused in the correct direction.  This article sums this all up for me.  "Of the close to 180,000 women diagnosed each year with breast cancer, approximately 37% are diagnosed with later-stage cancer every year, and still others have a breast cancer recurrence. Why? If mammography was going to be our cure, why hasn't breast cancer mortality declined dramatically after all these years?"  "What's the harm? The harm is that we've lost our focus for finding the real answers. We continue to fail those 40,000 women every year. We need less focus on "early detection" and more focus on understanding the reality of breast cancer - how to stop the aggressive cancers that aren't detected with mammography, how to stop breast cancer from recurring, and how to prevent it from metastasizing to other parts of the body and becoming lethal." For the whole article go here: http://news.cincinnati.com/article/20091012/EDIT02/910120349/1019/EDIT/Mammography%20isn%20t%20the%20cure-all%20we%20d%20hoped%20for

Posts.Content: Aug 18, 2009 09:33PM chainsawz wrote: My onc told me to stay on whatever is working until it doesn't work anymore.  I wanted to stop because I had just a few lung mets, but he encouraged me to keep getting herceptin because there was a possibility of other mets we just didn't see yet.  He also believed my mets were kept small by the herceptin and they might grow without it.  I recently discovered brain mets that were lurking there undetected, so I will be switching to tykerb\xeloda, but plan on adding herceptin back in when possible because I believe it really did keep the lung mets in check.   best wishes to you whatever you decide :>  lisa
Posts.Title: Am I crazy to want to stop Herceptin? ninismom DEAK95

Posts.Content: Aug 9, 2011 07:37PM chainsawz wrote: I started out stage iv 3 years ago and never imagined I'd still be here fartin' around, but I am with no plans on going anywhere for a long while.  I did create a hand-me-down box for my children and grandchildren.  I made a wedding bouquet out of sparkly antique brooches (I hope the pic posts here?)  Then I created a book to go in the box.  I have family trees, pictures of everyone in the tree and interesting things about them.  I also wrote to each of my kids about our lives together...funny stuff they did when they were little, etc.  I also put pictures of family heirlooms so they can connect to them thru the family tree and pictures.  I included any special recipes, etc.  Needless to say, I plan to be working on this for a long time, but it helps me get a sense of peace knowing nothing will be left unsaid.  xx00xx lisa

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2012 11:36AM chainsawz wrote: My tagliine comes from an old story I hreard from one of my native american frinds and it has always been a source of strength and inspiration to me....anyone who has spent time on some of the reservations knows the hardships that are endured by the people living there....and they keep going no matter what :>  A young man asked his grandfather why life had to be so difficult sometimes. This was the old man's reply. Grandfather says this: "In life there is sadness as well as joy, losing as well as winning, falling as well as standing, hunger as well as plenty, badness as well as goodness. I do not say this to make you despair, but to teach you reality. Life is a journey sometimes walked in light, sometimes walked in shadow." Grandfather says this: "You did not ask to be born, but you are here. You have weakness as well as strengths. You have both because in life there is two of everything. Within you is the will to win, as well as the willingness to lose. Within you is the heart to feel compassion as well as the smallness to be arrogant. Within you is the way to face life as well as the fear to turn away from it." Grandfather says this: "Life can give you strength. Strength can come from facing the storms of life, from knowing loss, feeling sadness and heartache, from falling into the depths of grief. You must stand up in the storm. You must face the wind and the cold and the darkness. When the storm blows hard you must stand firm, for it is not trying to knock you down, it is really trying to teach you to be strong." Grandfathers says this: "Being strong means taking one more step toward the top of the hill, no matter how weary you may be. It means letting the tears flow through the grief. It means to keep looking for the answer, though the darkness of despair is all around you. Being strong means to cling to hope for one more heartbeat, one more sunrise. Each step, no matter how difficult, is one more step closer to the top of the hill. To keep hope alive for one more heartbeat at a time leads to the light of the next sunrise, and the promise of a new day." Grandfather says this: "The weakest step toward the top of the hill, toward sunrise, toward hope, is stronger than the fiercest storm." Grandfather says this: "Keep going."

Posts.Content: Apr 12, 2010 03:38PM chainsawz wrote: Gads!  I am on tykerb and have the same problem and it is definitely gross and painful!  I soak my toe in epsom salts and also betadine.  After the soak I put two creams on.....one night I put on a high powered hydrocortisone (clobestral??) and the next night clinamyacine gel which is an antibiotic.  My last one took 3 months to heal completely but doing this helped with the redness and discomfort.  I have heard of many people getting oral antibotics and it may not be a bad idea for you.  Maybe you can get an RX from your onc and do the soaks to help?

Posts.Content: May 11, 2011 05:06PM - edited May 11, 2011 05:13PM by chainsawz Sorry you are having such a horrible time and eyebrow dandruff to top everything off...you sure needed that, huh?  And that damned navelbine!!  It's not tanking my counts, but boy it is hard on the body - I don't know how you do it?  I have horrible bone pain in my hips and back.  At first, I thought it was from laying in so many brain scanners in one week...sheesh!!  I'm glad to know that ibu doesn't sink platelets, because those and aleve really help.  Thanks for posting that because I was trying to avoid them and only stick with tylenol.  My vicoden makes me itch like crazy, too!  I've been taking benadryl with them and it seems to help a bit.  Anytime I have morphine, my nose itches like a mamma-jamma and I barf....so I ask for the big gun..phenergran....that stuff gives me an enormous sleepy buzz, but it takes all the itching, barfing and pain away! I hope they can find some balance for you and I'll be waiting for your brain results :>

Posts.Content: Dec 11, 2009 09:31PM chainsawz wrote: This is such a hard issue and I really don't know if anyone has the answers.  I didn't have any symptoms with my lung mets or my brain mets. I am very fortunate my brain mets were discovered early because my treatment options were vastly different because they were found early.  I don't think early detection made a difference for my lung mets.... However, I have had no less than 25 scans of one type of another in the last year due to my mets and a little heart thingy caused by xeloda....I am very sure I will experience serious repercussions in the future.  While it was awesome to find these things early, what price will I pay later because of the radiation and radioactive stuff I have been exposed to this last year....and in the years to come?  It feels like a crazy crap shoot!  It sounds like the "wait two weeks rule" might be the best balance.  Best to you!!  lisa

Posts.Content: Jan 6, 2010 07:23PM chainsawz wrote: Klee - Taxotere kicks your butt.  I also had 6 rounds of that sprinkled with a little carboplatin and it just made me exhausted and weepy.  I would cry because I was so tired of being tired.  It is one harsh chemo, but it does kick some cancer butt!  I felt alone and like no one cared, but I think it was because my family wasn't going thru the same hell I was and couldn't understand how much help I needed....and that I hated asking for everything.  That is very isolating all by itself. As for your pleural effusion - I hope you insist on twilight sedation if they drain.  I have lung mets and have been researching this and am pretty sure I want to be out for the procedure.  When I had my ct guided lung biopsy, they weren't going to sedate me and I told them when I experience pain I start screaming like a banshee and kick wildly.  They knocked me out cold :> I am sending you gentle hugs and I hope you get some relief soon, and that taxo-terrible will also knock the socks off your cancer!!

Posts.Content: Jul 8, 2010 03:34AM chainsawz wrote: I got an AWFUL rash all over my scalp and face.  Clinamycin gel (RX) really helps my face, but when the rash continued to get worse on my trunk/arms and I spiked a fever of 103..we reduced the dose.  Now I just the a few here and there each day...nothing big.  I was told that even tho these look like zits, they are not...they need to be treated like an infection and sometimes treated with an oral antibotic. The ones on my scalp are called folliculitis.   I'll tell ya, if I don't pop them they get really nasty, painful and leave a big huge scab.  They sure seem like monster pimples!    I named the huge one on my nose....chester.  Now thanks to clindamycin...chester is dead..LOL!!!

Posts.Content: May 19, 2010 04:45PM chainsawz wrote: I take mine before bed.  I started off with 1250 mg and now down to 1000 due to rash and the poop soup...bleck!  The tykerb trots started the next day for me, so if you can wait until after the wedding to start, I would.  I think everyone is different, but I still haven't heard of anyone taking tykerb an avoiding the diarrhea?  Before my dose reduction I took an immodium in the am and then another in the afternoon.  That cut my times down to 5-10 times a day, which for some odd reason seemed manageable?  Without the immodium it was 10-20 times a day.  I had to map out bathrooms everywhere I went and it was always a close call!!!  Now with the dose reduction I only take imm. a few times the week I get a herceptin treatment.  The pills are big, but they seem to go down pretty easy.  Hezzie had her pills put into a liquid form by the pharmacist....... Posts.Content: Feb 28, 2010 08:45PM chainsawz wrote: I did six rounds of TCH in the fall of 2008 and lost every hair on my body by the 5th treatment.  I have been on herceptin since, and my hair is now about 3 inches since herceptin can slow hair growth for some.  Some people have their hair grow back quickly, so I think it is different for everyone :>  I am still waiting for all my eyelashes to return!   I had hair down to my waist, and I can tell you the best thing I ever did was to get it cut short before I started chemo.  When it really started coming out it made a mess everywhere so I went ahead and had it shaved.  It did try to grow back while on chemo, but some of the stubbles would fall out.  I had some whispy hairs grow, but not much else until I was done with treatment.  You'll do great, and you may be one of those who don't lose all their hair!!

Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2011 05:47PM chainsawz wrote: Others who are hormone positive will come along and give better information, but I do know hormonals can give some many years before having to get chemo.  At stage IV, its about pacing since this is a marathon.  You want to plan everything out to give you the longest possible time.  Once a med fails it's on to the next one.  While there are many lines of defense, you want to make them last so others might be developed and come along. Unfortunately, there is no cure for stage IV.  Some people get months or years with NED (no evidence of disease) but many times its just lurking around so you don't want to let your guard down.  There is always hope!  My personal plan is to live another 40 years and I am going to try damn hard to get there....who knows??   Best to you!!   lisa

Posts.Content: Nov 18, 2009 12:04AM chainsawz wrote: I don't wear a bra (no recon), but I do have a problem with my seat belt in the car rubbing on my port.  I got a small little pouch with some stuffing (batting?) that I put between my port and the belt.  Maybe you can find something that will buffer your port a little?  I absolutely hated my port when I first got it last August.  Now over a year later, I love it.  Chemo is very hard on the veins and sometimes I see people getting poked for a IV for over an hour and it looks very painful.  I just get clicked in and I am off and running with no pain.  Hang in there, it will get better :> Hopefully someone will come along and post and idea about a cool thing to help with the bra rubbing.  If not, maybe this is your opportunity to invent something for those who suffer with this problem :>  Best to you!!  lisa

Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2011 11:46PM - edited Feb 19, 2011 11:48PM by chainsawz Thanks for bumping this KK....I don't check in on the weekends too much.  I am not TN, but I also had 2 small brain mets treated with SRS 08/09.   I also have lung mets which are not behaving very well recently and in March I am having the same SRS treatment to the two narsty lung nodules.  I will then mop it up with some more chemo.  I'm not sure which one yet.  I do have a chemo buddy who is triple negative......she was dx 8 months before me (in 2008).  She also has lung mets.  Her first chemos - taxol and avastin - wiped them out and kept her clear for over 2 years.  Recently, she got another lung nodule.  She had the same procedure I am (SRS)...in fact, we go to the same rad onc.  She has now switched to abraxane and is doing very well.  From what I hear, TN cancer can respond well to chemo.  Feel free to PM me anytime....you are not alone!!

Posts.Content: Feb 20, 2011 06:02PM chainsawz wrote: Those are great links from EnglishMajor - both sites have tons of information.  I did indeed have active lung mets when my brain mets were found.  I started out stage IV with lung mets and a year after dx my brain mets were found.  I am her2+ and I believe the treatments for TN and her2+ are different when it comes to brain mets.  I wish I had more information for TN, but hopefully the brainmetsbc.org can shed some light.  SRS (stereotactic radiosurgery) is similar to cyberknife.  Here is another great site: http://bcwatchdigest.evidencewatch.com/   It is run by Constantine who I have seen help another TN patient wade thru the brain mets information.  There is a link on the top label brain mets, and another triple negative.  Treatment options are a very personal decision.  I weighed my options and took a leap.  No way to know exactly what is the right path...just what feels right to your wife and her treatment team.  Best to you!!

Posts.Content: Feb 2, 2010 12:02PM chainsawz wrote: Brain mets definitely are scary, but there is always hope!   The founder of her2support.org had brain mets treated successfully over 10 years ago.  There are other stories like that all over the place!  It is true that tykerb and neratinib are believed to pass the BBB and help control brain mets.  I had my brain mets zapped with SRS (no WBR)  and have had 2 clear brain mri's since.  If I have a recurrance, I will get those zapped.  This is going to sound very weird to say, but a certain percentage of her2+ BC patients have brain mets and never even know it....it's not what did them in.  Please don't read the statistics.......WE are making the statistics now.  They tend to clump her2+ patients in with all cancer patients with brain mets, so the stats IMO are skewed.  Didn't Mark Twain say there are statistics, damned lies and more damed lies.....or something like that?  I can't quite remember.  Just know there is lots of hope for you no matter what those doctors say.  This is new territory and they don't know it all.  I have been teaching my team they cannot make assumptions!!   I went to a site called  http://bcwatchdigest.evidencewatch.com/ and did some reading.  The rad onc and neurosurgeon planted their feet and wanted to give me WBR.  After reading the studies on this site, I discovered that it was possible for my mets to refused WBR and only get SRS.  That is not the case for all mets, but doing the research will help you understand and fight for what you want.  It is noted in the studies on this site, that smaller mets can be treated successfully with SRS and no WBR.  Depends on the number, size and swelling.  Something for you to check out.  I am not opposed to WBR, I just want to keep more options open for me in the future :>  Take a deep breath and just put one foot in front of the other.......that's how I get thru the day!

Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2010 01:38PM chainsawz wrote: Brain mets is definitely scary stuff, but there is always lots of hope!  I had 2 brain mets found 07/09, and had SRS (like cyberknife) to treat them....my brain is currently clear.  I see your mom is her2+....many who are Her2+ with brain mets that respond to treatment are living for years....it is possible!  It also means she is eligible for tykerb.  It's similar to herceptin but is used when that fails.  Herceptin didn't hold the line for me, but I had tykerb added to my herceptin and it is doing great stuff!    Tykerb is believed to pass the BBB (blood brain barrier) to help treat the brain mets.  Neratinib is also another chemo believed to pass the BBB so that is another option. Do you know how many mets your mom has and the size?  Those two factors determine what type of treatment plan she will receive and if she has to have WBR (whole brain radiation) or can just have cyberknife treatment.  We are all here for you!  Best to you and your mom!   lisa

Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2010 05:46PM chainsawz wrote: Cancersuks - a brain MRI is nothing to be afraid of.....I am a firm believer in the idea that finding it sooner is much better than later.  Keep your eyes open and you stab the monster in the heart....keep them closed and you may miss.  I found my brain mets early and had them zapped...yay!!  I went to work the next day after the painless procedure.  That was 7 months ago.  Since they were small, I didn't have an side effects from the mets...in fact, I didn't even know they were there.  If I had waited until I had symptoms my treatment would have been much different and I would be experiencing SE.  Many patients enjoy wonderful lives despite brain mets....heck, I still work full time!   I think all mets are equally scary.....IMO :>   xx00xx lisa

Posts.Content: Oct 26, 2009 06:04PM chainsawz wrote: I found some pictures in the 'photographs' section of BreastFree.org (breastfree.org/viewer.php?num=22)  I knew what to expect after my bilateral mastectomy - take a look there :>  It is difficult to find any pictures that do not involve reconstruction...not sure why? At first, my scars were puckered like a shar pei dog, but my surgeon assured me those would smooth out after a few months and they did!  My scars are smooth and are almost straight lines a year later and I am happy.  I was suprised that I have a little area that caves in a bit on one side.  I did some research and found that each side of the body is different - in this case the my rib cage on one side sticks out farther than the other.  It's not really noticeable, but I could exercise to build up muscle.....if I ever got motivated...LOL!!     It will take a few months for the swelling to resolve and everything to start settling so give it a little time and it will look better and you will have great looking noobes (no boobs), too!  Hang in there!!  lisa
